Award.AwardTitle: Some Analytical Aspects of the Theory of Integrable Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The class of equations under study, called integrable systems, includes several fundamental equations of nature. This is an old and venerable area of study which goes back to classical works of Liouville, Gauss, and Poincare. Currently, the theory of integrable systems has become an expanding area which plays an increasingly important role as one of the principal sources of new ideas for many branches of modern mathematics and theoretical physics. Simultaneously, it provides an efficient analytical tool for the study of some of the fundamental mathematical models arising in modern nonlinear science and technology. In addition to the traditional domain of differential equations, integrable techniques are becoming common in such diverse fields as string theory, statistical mechanics, random processes, quantum informatics, and number theory. Many of the problems considered in the project have direct connections with these disciplines. Indeed, the concrete analytical questions addressed in the project are primarily motivated by the needs of the analytical theory of quantum entanglement - a phenomenon which is expected to play a key role in a practical realization of quantum computing, and by the challenges of analytical description of fundamental issue of phase transition in the quantum and statistical mechanics.



The principal goal of this research project is to address various new analytical questions of the theory of integrable systems which have emerged from recent developments in random matrix theory and in the theory of exactly solvable quantum models. In this project, the PI proposes to focus on three directions of research: the asymptotic analysis of Toeplitz and Hankel determinants and the applications of these determinants in random matrices and statistical mechanics, the study of Fredholm determinants arising in random matrix theory, and the asymptotics of the correlation functions of non-free fermionic quantum spin models. Each of these directions is represented by a collection of concrete problems, and they will be investigated within the same analytical framework, viz., the Riemann-Hilbert method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELECTUAL MERIT

The proposed project is a continuation of the PI's long term research efforts
in the theory of Integrable systems and their numerous applications.


The term ``Integrable Systems''  usually refers to mathematical objects, most often
differential equations, with  special  symmetry properties  which allow to study
them in a very detailed way and sometimes even to solve them  in a closed form.
The class of integrable systems includes  several fundamental equations of nature, and
the mathematical foundations of integrable systems go back to classical works
of Liouville, Gauss, and Poincare. In our days, the theory of integrable systems
has become  an expanding area  which is one of the principal sources
of new analytical and algebraic ideas for many branches of modern mathematics
and theoretical physics. Simultaneously,  it provides an efficient analytical tool for
the study of some of the fundamental  mathematical models arising in  modern
nonlinear science and technology. In addition to the traditional domain  of
differential equations, integrable techniques are becoming  common in
 such diverse fields  as orthogonal polynomials,  string theory, enumerative topology,
 statistical mechanics, random processes,  quantum informatics,  and number theory.
 Many of the  problems which was considered in the project   have direct connections
 with these disciplines.


The project  was devoted to the investigation of  the  various  new analytical questions
of the theory of integrable systems which have emerged from  recent developments in
random matrix theory and in the theory of exactly solvable quantum models.
The main focus of the project was on the problems related to the Toeplitz, Hankel,
and Fredholm determinants and on the special class of functions known
as Painlev\'e transcendents. These analytic objects  were introduced in mathematical
analysis at the turn of  the last century and, starting from the middle of the century,
have been among the principal analytic tools in the above indicated fields.
The main results of this three year research  program are the following.


(a) The complete description of the double scaling transition between the Gaussian
and the linear exponential behaviors of the sine-kernel Fredholm  determinant
(together with T. Bothner, P. Deift and I. Krasovsky).

(b) The proof of the long-standing conjecture of Basor and Tracy
concerning the asymptotics of Toeplitz determinants
with a Fisher-Hartwig symbol  of general form (together with P. Deift
and I. Krasovsky).

(c) The asymptotic solution (together with K. Kozlowski) of the  operator - valued
Riemann-Hilbert problem arising   in the analysis  of the theory of of the two principal
quantum spin  models - the  XXZ and  XXX  spin 1/2 Heisenberg chains.

Each of the above reported results constitute the solution of a long-standing
problem of the field.

In addition, a new research program have been launched. It is concerned
with the theory  of Painlev\'e  tau functions which are playing increasingly
important role in many areas of the modern mathematics and theoretical physics;
indeed, the Painleve functions are dubbed as the ``special functions of the
XXIst century''.

BROADER IMPACT

The analysis of the double scaling limit of the sine-kernel
determinant produces a quantitate description of very interesting phenomenon -
the   transition between  Poisson statistic and random matrix statistics in
the one dimensional Coulomb gas model  introduced in 1995 by Freeman Dyson.

The results of the PI and his collaborators concerning  the asymptotic analysis
of Toeplitz and Hankel determinants contribute to the study  of critical phenomena
in statistical mechanics - an enduring, fundamental problem in the field. 
Specifically, the proof of the Basor-Tracy conjecture and the asymptotics of
the T+H determinants obtained by the PI with his co-workers  have already
made it possible to justify  various  asymptotic formulae that appeared 
previously in the physical literature on  the basis of this conjecture.
These results have also been used in condensed matter physics
in recent studies of  quantum many-body systems  away  from
equilibrium and in testing  random matrix predictions in number theory.

The asymptotic solution of the operator - valued Riemann-Hilbert problem obtained  by the PIwith hiscollabotartor  makes animportant contribution towards resolution   of  one of the
most ``wanted'' problems in modern theory of integrable systems which is 
to develop  a rigorous approach to the evaluation of the
long distance asymptotics of the  correlation functions of the XXX and XXZ Heisenberg spin chains.



During the entire period of the award, the  PI has been engaged in many
educational activities: he has given five mini-courses in various world scientific
centers, has  supervised three graduate students (one successfully defended
his PhD in  2013), and has given  in total 62  invited  presentations
including three Plenary Talks. Also, during the same period, the PI has published  24 
research papers  in the major refereed  journals.
